TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( PERSON ) gave judgment ordering a certain ORG to pay the applicant MONEY ( DEM ) . The judgment became final and enforceable on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant sought enforcement of the above judgment . On DATE ORG ( PERSON u ORG ) issued an enforcement order . It decided to seize ORG 's movable property and sell it at a public auction . On DATE the applicant informed the court that he advanced the costs of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . The court bailiff attempted to conduct the first on - site inspection on DATE , but ORG was not found on the address provided by the applicant . His parents , PERSON and PERSON , informed the bailiff that PERSON had not lived at that address for DATE .

CARDINAL . The court scheduled another on - site inspection for DATE . However , the court bailiff could not enter ORG house , because it was locked . On DATE the applicant asked the court to set another date for the bailiff 's intervention with the assistance of the police and the locksmith . He also requested temporary seizure of ORG 's passport .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court held a hearing . It invited the applicant to again advance the costs and scheduled another on - site inspection for DATE . The inspection again failed since ORG 's house was locked . On DATE the applicant requested the temporary seizure of S.R 's passport .

CARDINAL . The court scheduled yet another on - site inspection for DATE , with the assistance of the police and a locksmith . On DATE , the court bailiff entered ORG house and seized the following movables : CARDINAL motorbikes , a lawnmower , a welding machine , a TV and a stereo . DATE , the applicant repeated his request for seizure of the passport .

CARDINAL . On DATE the debtor 's parents as third parties filed an objection against the enforcement on the seized movables , claiming they were the owners of the seized property which could therefore not be the object of enforcement . On DATE the court invited the applicant to respond to the objection raised . DATE the applicant did so by contesting the third parties ' allegations .

CARDINAL . NORP On DATE the applicant repeated his request for temporary seizure of ORG 's passport . Finally , on DATE the court dismissed the applicant 's motion in this respect . On appeal , on DATE the second - instance court upheld the first - instance decision finding that the seizure of the passport was not allowed under the legislation in force .
CARDINAL . On DATE the court inquired with the police about ORG 's place of residence . The police replied that PERSON left for GPE .
CARDINAL . Subsequently , on DATE the applicant invited the court to continue with the enforcement on the seized movables .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court instructed ORG 's parents , to institute separate civil proceedings to declare the enforcement on the seized movables inadmissible . The third parties did so and it would appear that those proceedings are still pending .
CARDINAL . The relevant part of CARDINAL of LAW on LAW ( Ustavni zakon o PERSON , ORG no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE – “ LAW ” ) reads as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) The Constitutional Court shall examine a constitutional complaint whether or not all legal remedies have been exhausted if the competent court fails to decide a claim concerning the applicant 's rights and obligations or a criminal charge against him or her within a reasonable time ...

( CARDINAL ) If a constitutional complaint ... under paragraph CARDINAL of this section is upheld , the Constitutional Court shall set a time - limit within which the competent court must decide the case on the merits ...

( CARDINAL ) In a decision issued under paragraph CARDINAL of this section , the Constitutional Court shall assess appropriate compensation for the applicant for the violation of his or her constitutional rights ... The compensation shall be paid out of the ORG budget within DATE from the date a request for payment is lodged . ”

CARDINAL . Under the case - law of ORG , constitutional complaints lodged under section CARDINAL in the context of enforcement proceedings were to be declared inadmissible . In its decision no . U - IIIA/CARDINAL/CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE ORG interpreted section CARDINAL as follows :

“ The Constitutional Court shall institute proceedings pursuant to a constitutional complaint lodged under section CARDINAL of LAW [ on FAC ] for the length of proceedings only in cases where the court has not decided within a reasonable time on the merits of the rights and obligations of the complainant , that is , where it has failed to deliver a decision on the merits within a reasonable time .
In the present case the constitutional complaint has been lodged for non - enforcement of a final decision by which the party 's rights and obligations had already been decided .
Taking into consideration the above cited provisions of LAW [ on LAW ] ... , ORG is of the opinion that in this case the conditions for applicability of section CARDINAL were not met . ”
In its decision no . U - IIIA/CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE the ORG provided further interpretation of CARDINAL :

“ Taking into consideration the above cited provisions of LAW [ on ORG ] and the fact that the constitutional complaint was not lodged for a failure to deliver a decision within a reasonable time but rather because the enforcement was not carried out , ORG is of the opinion that in this case the conditions for applicability of CARDINAL were not met . ”

CARDINAL . In decision no . U - IIIA/CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE ORG changed its practice , accepting a constitutional complaint and awarding compensation as well as ordering the competent court to conclude the enforcement proceedings within DATE from its decision . In doing so , ORG expressly relied on the ORG 's case - law on the matter .
